b"b' Replace jar distribution strategy with bittorrent'"
b'b" Addresses:url  This just uses bittorrent for moving the topology jar files around
column11: the serialized conf and topology still go through the thrift API. When nimbus starts up
column12: it will create a tracker on port 6969. When a topology is deployed
column13: nimbus will create a torrent file
column15: and start seeding (it will seed until the topology is killed). Supervisors will grab the .torrent and use it to download the topology jar. Supervisors will share pieces during the download
column16: but will not continue to seed once the download completes. I\'m open to any change in this behavior  class naming
column17: etc. I didn\'t update the logback config
column18: but the ttorrent client is pretty chatty at the INFO level. It might be a good idea to turn that off. The bittorrent client url  is not available in a public maven repo
column19: as far as I can tell
column20: but it is simple to build."'

column10: b'b" This overlaps some with the HA Nimbus work
column11: but the two can work together. For example
column12: torrent files can list multiple trackers (I.e. nimbus). I\'ll take a closer look at the ha stuff when I\'m not on a phone. ;)"'

column10: b'b" We should have all topology files (conf etc.) managed by this system. This will make HA Nimbus much easier and remove the need for the storage abstraction and dependencies on external systems like HDFS. We can set a policy that at least N Nimbus\'s need to have the full topology files before the topology gets launched (but files will eventually be copied to all Nimbus\'s if more than N).  Is it possible to set max download and upload throughputs on each node? We would want to set these limits to prevent supervisors from taking on too much load from this. As for the Bittorrent library
column11: I can just upload that to the same Maven repo used for other Storm jars once this pull request is done."'

column10: b'b" Then the way to go is to package everything in one multi-file torrent (
column12: topo-)
column13: and distribute that.. That\'s a relatively easy change... Do you want me to add that? As for throughput
column14: the way I have it now is nimbus will take the most load
column15: depending on the size of the .jar. If it is massive
column16: then there will be more sharing between supervisor clients. Otherwise
column17: the supervisors may get the parts from nimbus before they discover the other supervisor seeds. I\'ll also look into what throttling options are available

column10: b'b" OK. The throttling is really important
column11: so I won\'t merge this in until that\'s in place. We can make the throttle amounts configurable via the ."'

column10: b'b\' I delved into the tttorrent code and found that it does not support throttling  rates
column11: but I will look into what it would take to add it. Can you elaborate on your concern with the supervisors taking on too much load? In the current approach
column12: only nimbus acts as a seeder. The supervisors act as leechers and stop sharing as soon as they complete the download. The supervisors never seed. For the most part
column13: the supervisors will prefer downloading parts from nimbus (since nimbus has the complete file)
column14: and only share amongst themselves while downloading if a supervisor peer could offer a part with better performance than the nimbus peer. So the supervisors are "download heavy" and the nimbus\\\'s are "upload heavy". I\\\'ll move forward with including all topology files as part of the torrent download. Let me know if you still think lack of throttling is a showstopper
column15: and I\\\'ll look into  that feature for ttorrent.\''

column10: b"b' I love the idea of using bit-torrent
column11: but bit-torrent does not support authentication or authorization
column12: except through extensions like url  that ttorrent does not support.  This is a bit of a regression as the current thrift APIs do have the beginnings of auth.  Seeing how this code does not yet remove the thrift  APIs would it be possible to have the distribution mechanism configurable until we can work out the auth model?'"

column10: b'b" This is a case where making it pluggable increases complexity. The Bittorrent based distribution greatly simplifies the construction of HA Nimbus (completely removes reliance on external systems)
column11: and it is clearly the optimal approach for distributing static files around the cluster. So I\'d like us to figure out how to support our auth needs (or at least have a plan for it) within the context of a Bittorrent based approach. Perhaps this will require modifications to ttorrent
column12: and that\'s fine. @ptgoetz So the reason for the importance of throttling is it provides a guarantee of load on a supervisor. First of all
column13: I think supervisors should be allowed to seed files and participate in sharing after they\'ve finished downloading. This ensures jar distribution is fast and scalable to large clusters. But we need to make sure that the distribution process can only have a limited effect on active topologies \\xe2\\x80\\x93\\xc2\\xa0hence the throttling. Resource usage should always be explicit and not rely on implicit effects of the design. Things change
column14: and my experience has repeatedly shown that if you want a guarantee
column15: you must be explicit about it."'

column10: b"b' I understand the desire to not clutter things up too much with plug-ability.  I am fine with just having a plan for auth initially. I am also happy to help implement it.  I just want to be sure that it is not missed.'"
b"b' Absolutely
column11: you brought up a great point regarding auth.'"

column10: b'b" Ok. I will update the code so all the topology files are distributed via BitTorrent. Are you willing to accept BitTorrent throttling (and auth) as separate pull requests? For those I will need to fork the ttorrent project and make the necessary modifications
column11: which may take a while. IMHO
column12: the switch to BitTorrent is a good first step toward HA
column13: and the choking mechanism in the BitTorrent protocol will help alleviate overload on supervisors. When the BitTorrent feature is in place
column14: the planned HA features can move forward. When throttling is available
column15: it would be a simple addition (I could even put the hooks in place now). I can also add a configurable seed duration for supervisors (e.g. Don\'t seed

column10: b"b' Throttling will have to be part of this pull request
column11: auth can be in a separate pull request.'"

column10: b'b\' I dove into the ttorrent code last night and have a crude
column11: but functional means of throttling throughput. Now I have a question and a caveat. The question is
column12: do you want to throttle at the peer level
column13: or the torrent level? I\\\'m assuming the torrent level so I\\\'m headed in that direction. The caveat is that the throttling is not exact
column14: nor is the  of throuhput. So setting max  thresholds is more like a "hint." For example if I set a threshold of 50 .
column15: the actual throughput will fluctuate between ~45-55 . but average very close to 50. The ttorrent logs will also report inaccurate throughputs. But testing with several bittorrent clients
column16: throughput was very close to the requested threshold. Let me know if that\\\'s okay and I\\\'ll proceed. Thanks

column10: b'b\' Well we\\\'d want to throttle the overall rate for the supervisor. I think that\\\'s what you mean by "peer". If the easiest way to do that is to restrict the supervisor to downloading / sharing one torrent at a time
column11: that could be an acceptable first step. And then we\\\'ll open up an issue to fix that. The trick if taking that implementation strategy is choosing which torrent that supervisor should share. We\\\'d also want to add a special case for when the supervisor has no active workers in which there would be no  limits. I think it\\\'s ok for there to be minor fluctuation in the  rate.\''

column10: b"b' Mods to ttorrent are here: url '"
b"b' @ptgoetz So that implements peer-level throttling?'"

b'b\' @nathanmarz  Throttling has been added to ttorrent at the _torrent_ level: url  But a potential bug was introduced in a separate pull request that got merged around the same time mine did: url  So if you want to see it action
column11: I\\\'d suggest pulling from my  until that gets sorted out. The throttling in ttorrent works like so:A ttorrent client instance has exactly one torrent.The client can share () with _n_ peers (a _peer_ is just another client that participates in ). rate limits are set at the  level
column12: the amount each peer is throttled will depend on how many peers are connected. For example
column13: if you have a client sharing a torrent with 5 leeching (downloading) peers
column14: and you set the max upload rate to 50 .
column15: each downloading peer will only get 10 . If 4 of the 5 leechers stop downloading (or disconnect)
column16: the remaining downloading peer will be able to download at 50 . **How I see this playing out in storm:** (I\\\'m totally open to suggestions
column17: etc.)Nimbus(\\\'s)/Supervisors will have separate global  rate limits (a limit <= 0.0 == unlimited)."Toplogy Torrents" will contain:
column19: (let me know if I\\\'m missing anything).Each  will have 1 topology torrent for every deployed topology. (right now I\\\'m naming the file "${storm-id}.torrent")If a rate limit is set for
column20: the amount of bandwidth allocated to each  will depend on the number of deployed topologies. For example
column21: if I set and there are two  topologies deployed
column22: the 50 . bandwidth will be split between the two (25  each). Killing one of the two toplogies will rebalance the bandwidth allocation
column23: so the remaining toplogy will then get the full 50 . Seeding:By default
column24: Nimbus will seed a topology torrent until the topology is killed.Supervisors can be configured with: download-only
column26: seed-indefinitely Is that an acceptable feature set for this pull request? I\\\'d like to nail down those features and move on to sorting the ramifications it will have on
column27: et. al. There\\\'s some logic in there that I have yet to fully grok (sync
column30: and I may need to lean on you for some  to make sure everything\\\'s right.  I\\\'m still in a WIP state at this point
column31: but largely functional. I can deploy a topology such that all its files are distributed (and rate limited) via bittorrent
column33: and supervisor will recover from  -ing a worker. (I should also note that I haven\\\'t pushed many of the above changes yet). -Taylor\''

column11: and don\'t see ZK will face challenges to deal with torrent files."'

column10: b"b' I also tested this merged with the 0.9.0-rc2 code on a 5 node cluster with a 70MB topology jar and topology startup was pretty fast.'"
b"b' @anfeng I thought about storing the .torrent in ZK
column11: but ultimately decided against it. I was afraid of hitting some edge case where the size of the .torrent file exceeded the 1MB limit. My gut instinct is to keep it that way for now. In the future
column12: however
column13: ttorrent will likely support magnet links. Then the ZK route would definitely be the way to go since all we would have to store in ZK would be a URI.'"

column10: b"b' @ptgoetz  I guess this is due to the limitation of  bittorrent client lib. In a more advanced client lib
column11: you could specify chunk size for torrent creation. At Yahoo
column12: we have been using such features to ensure torrent size <= 40KB.'"

column10: b'b" @anfeng  Out of curiosity what client lib are you using at yahoo? The ttorrent maintainer is great about contributions (I contributed bandwidth throttling to support this pull request). I\'m sure he\'d be open to implementing configurable piece size -and most of the groundwork is already there. Nonetheless
column11: I would still prefer the magnet link approach over storing files in ZK. I generally avoid putting files ZK unless there is a definite guarantee that the size limit won\'t be exceeded. Eventually someone will include blueray rip of the Star Wars collection in their topology jar. ;) Anyway
column12: would you be willing to move forward with this if we add an issue for completely eliminating the file transfer code from the nimbus interface? This pull request greases the wheels for HA nimbus. That work will likely involve a lot of ZK work (leader election
column14: and might be a good time to address this. I can also look into what it would take to get magnet link support added to ttorrent. Some work has already been done in that are
column15: but I\'m not sure where it stands. Thoughts?"'

column13: or (2) controling chunk size. At Yahoo
column14: we have a file distribution solution based on libtorrent url Please take a look at url  \\\\*  create_torrent (file_storage& fs

column17: a piece_size will be calculated such that the torrent file is roughly 40 KB.'"

column10: b'b" I agree that having Nimbus be completely stateless would be ideal
column11: but I do think that it\'s worth getting this pull request merged in even if Nimbus has to distribute .torrent files. The shift to Bittorrent distribution from the current approach is a much bigger shift than moving to magnet links. It\'s important that we get this into people\'s hands so that it can be tested and ironed out. That said
column12: we should target this for 0.9.1 (from Apache release) rather than 0.9.0
column13: since RC\'s shouldn\'t add major new features. Perhaps we can get the full Nimbus HA implementation done for that release as well. Also
column14: I\'m not sure if you were suggesting this but using libtorrent is a non-starter. Let\'s keep all dependencies Java-based. We had enough headaches already with 0mq native dependency issues."'
